INSTRUCTION
HAVE been asked to present for our consideration to day
some educational principles
that bear most directly upon the instruction of college
classes. It is a field that has
never been seriously entered upon with a scientific spirit
Educators, and by this
term I mean student
s of education, have not done so, for not only the reason that the proper
education of the masses in the common and secondary schools
has appealed to them more
strongly, but for the further reason that practically from
this source alone has come the
demand for their services.
The college instructor seemingly has felt little need for
reflection upon questions of
method; in fact, many of them have been afforded much
amusement in the contemplation
of the serious manner
in which questions that seemed utter foolishness to them, were considered. A careful and thorough investigation as to the ways
in which the college students
Should be dealt with in order to accomplish for them
the maximum good has been con
demned as useless and inane. The college instructor has
been content with doing as his
old teachers had done before
him, except perhaps where he has been influenced by the university ideals, either because he honestly thinks its mode
of procedure is the method for the
lower, as well as for the higher institutions, or that it gives
him more time to himself for
further study and research Whether these be the true reasons
, or whether there be others,
the fact still remains that there
has never been an attempt of any consequence at a scientific formulation of educational principles for the college.
In justice to the college man it must, however, be said, that
were all other considera
tious equal, there is not for him so great a need for an elabora
tion of educational doctrines,
for in the individuals of 18 to 22 individuality
enters more into the formation of character
than does environment. Then, too, definiteness
of cla4sifleation and generality of laws are!
not Possible to nearly so great an extent as with childre
n, for individuals become through
habit more w idely differentiated with each successive year.
Yet this fact does not prove, it
seems to me, that it is not worth while; that it is not a practical underta
king. If fewer
generalizations can be formulated, and of these have a greater number of excepti
ons, this
condition will not gainsay the existence of certain fundamental laws which
are far-reaching in their application, and which if recognized, would result in
a higher quality of product in student acquisition and capacity.
It will be my endeavor to-day to present some facts that have been establis
hed by
scientific method, to draw from them certain general principles; and then to make
some
application of them to college life as we find it to-day. Let me disclaim at the outset
any
inference of personal investigation or of infallibility in these conclusions, or of pretent
iousness in this paper I have simply gathered together facts which seem to
me to have been
well established by others, and have reasoned from these facts to my conclus
ions. The
only claim for originality that could be considered is the point
of view, and it is original
only in reference to the subject treated.
The science of education has a three fold basis, three auxiliary sciences
; physiology
furnishes it with its laws of physical processes and development; from psychol
ogy it
secures its laws of mental action and growth; while the sociological sciences
provide its
ideals. The proper adjustment and correlation of the laws from these three
fields result in
true educational principles. The facts which I am to present to-day,
however, are to be

The college boy or girl is, in the language of genetic psychology, an adolescent. This
stage of the development of the individual is marked off at its beginning by the advent of
puberty and at its close by the full maturity of the reproductive organs. In boys this
covers the time front about the fourteenth to the twenty fifth year, and in girls front about
the thirteenth to the twenty•second year. The college student is, thus, in the latter part
of this stage of development. We shall then have to inquire into the characteristics of the
adolescent in general, and then call especial attention to the manner and extent of the
manifestations of those characteristics in the latter part of this stage of development.
Rousseau defines this period as the time when the child is born again, having at birth
been born cc an individual, and itow into the life of the race. There is much truth in this
statement, even though we may not wish to follow it out to all its logical consequences.
The addition of the sexual functions to his
The child is in many respects "born again.
bodily organism, wi.h the changes in bodily carriage, facial features, and the increased
growth and strength is sufficient to warrant the use of such language. And, indeed, its
importance has, so far as we know, been ever recognized even among uncivilized tribes
But front the mental standpoint the change is even more marked. And since it is this
alone that concerns us today, we may pass on without further comment upon the physical
development of this period, and the laws of physical hygiene to be observed during its
continuance.
Accompanying these physical changes there is a tremendous increase in the store of
nervous energy, which must have some outlet. He is fully awakened and aroused to
everything in his environment. Everything takes on a new meaning because he penetrates
deeper into the inter relations of things, and for the first time the interpretation of events
and things given by the adult, begins to dawn in its reality. The change in point of view
from that of the girl to that of the adult takes place rapidly, far more so than most of us
think, and in its non.recognition lie many of the errors of parents and teachers to day.
One day he is a boy, the next he is a man, is almost literally true. Certainly the time of
transition is not many months in length. To be sure, the way has been prepared, and the
observer can easily see the bearing of the acts of the pre-adolescent toward this culmination
period, and to the careless observer there seems no distant separation, but I thoroughly
believe that there is a time when the boy or girl conies to a distinct consciousness that now
I am a man or a woman, whereas, before I was a boy or a girl, and that from that time
there is such a new element in his personality, discernable to the keen sympathetic companion, that must be reckoned with in all dealings with him to such an extent as to
require in some respects a radically different attitude toward him.
In this great outpouring of nervous energy into new channels, naturally the emotional
side is most in evidence. The new desires, the new interests which must necessarily result from this great outpouring, cannot help going to great and extreme bounds in their
manifestations. Use is made of the intellectual powers already possessed in the new
fields, but those powers are limited necessarily. Judgment and reason and experience being deficient, what wonder is it that there are such ludicrous hopes, such senseless dreams,
such impossible ambitions as are secretly guiding the acts, and really almost entirely the
being the lives of these young people It is not often that another is allowed, to enter this
holy of holies; but we can easily conjecture what is therein, and so help take care of the
treasure that it may some day yield its full increase in the service of the world. This is
the key which unlocks the gate to the avenue of success for all those who are concerned
with the development of youth into true vigorous adulthood—the protection of this holy of
holies, seeing as far as is possible only those things which count for good remain long
therein.
A further analysis of the emotions is necessary. First and most important, and true in
all the other sides of mental life as well, there is a striking difference in the emotional

life of different individuals Each case stands alone; no two are seemingly exactly alike.
This might be interpreted to mean that there is no generalization possible; but we go on.
Second, the emotional life is very intense, there are strong loves, deep hatreds, bitter jealousies, strong rivalries, cordial loyalties, wonderful displays of courage. The individual
i8 quite apt to be unduly proud or modest. Third, the emotional life is fitful; there are
times of extreme elation and depression. Fourth, it is for the most part altruistic, extreme
cases of self sacrifice being common. Fifth, they reach out to many sides of the environment, the interests awakened are wide ranged. Sixth. they are directed in upon themyes—introspective. Seventh, at the beginning they are non-intellectualized, that is,
they are not under the control of the reason.
Turning next to the intellectual life of the adolescent, we find these new increased and
deeper interests causing more keen perceptions over a wider range of matter. Wider gen eralization, and more definiteness and accuracy in the analysis and synthesis of more
abundant details are possible. That is, his capacity has grown both extensively and in.
. He can embrace a wider range, and at the same time keep in hand a more refined elaboration of the facts already known as wholes. It is the age of the reason preeminently, when each for himself establishes the interrelatedness of things in his own life
and in his environment It differs from the previous age in that in the former he does not
inquire into the interdependences of phenomena in any more than a superficial way. He
takes the explanations offered as sufficient, and is not disposed to go back of them. While
in this latter period this new energy forces him beyond, and he will not be satisfied until
he has exhausted for himself all those resources which he can command or comprehend.
In the execution of his thoughts and desires, the adolescent at this period for the first
time really enters upon the plane of independent action. He feels the power within him
to do as he pleases. The influence of parents is apt to diminish, unless he is approached upon
this new plane; authority as represented in the school declines as well, if not properly
adapted. In any case he obeys the tribunal within his own mind; he has become fully
self-determining. He obeys not from force of compulsion, but of his own inner freedom,
and he wishes to be held responsible for his acts. His acts of will will now be much
longer sustained than formerly; he has greater powers of application with frequent spells
of inaction and activity, occuring less often with advancing age; he is not so easily turned
aside from the accomplishment of his desires. All in all, it is a time of intense, enthusiastic, indedendent activity.
Morally, the adolescent is an uncertain quantity, in some cases almost wholly good, in
others almost wholly bad, usually an admixture of the two, and his life is the struggle for
the mastery by these two forces. Extreme cases of evil in youths, whose acts are usually
strictly moral, are not really so abnormal as most people think. On the opposite extreme
We meet self infliction of penance in an undue degree for little or imaginary wrongs. It
is the time when vows and pledges are made, and when the religious life is intelligently
entered upon. There is in all this a patient persistent seeking for the foundation and true
interpretation of things in the moral life, as well as in the strictly intellectual.
He becomes more active in his social relations than ever before. The realization that
he is but a unit in a great social whole, upon which he is dependent, and from which he
gains most that he has, and to which he must in turn contribute his share begins to make
itself felt gradually. The institutions of society take on a new meaning, and he re-adapts
himself to them in a new way. He plans as to what place he shall take in the social group,
inquires into its constitution more closely, find weaknesses or needs and plans reforms.
Methods whereby his fellows may be united for the accomplishment of some end which
he has in view, with himself at the head, are studied and put into practice. The closest
friendships of life, and which often last through its course, are at this time formed, as well
as those loves which later develop into the relations of the marital life.
HARLAN UPDEGRAFF.

HE second of the open meetings of The Pedagogical Club was attended by
a large number of students, both graduate and undergraduate, last Saturday. It seems evidently fitting that, in an institution in which so large a
percentage of the students are prepared to teach, subjects similar to that which
was treated last Saturday should be discussed. Mr. Updegraff's address on
"Some Educational Principles Underlying College Instruction" was a revelation
to some of those who are inclined to be skeptical concerning the importance of
method in college teaching. The suggestion that the library of the col'ege
should be provided with several copies of the texts used for collateral reading
appealed very strongly to some ot the undergraduates who were present.
The Pedagogical Club is a student organization which, it seems to us,
should appeal to all men who expect to teach; and, if the discussions which
take place at the regular meetings of the Club are as interesting to the general
student as was last Saturday's address, we believe that any student would
receive both profit and pleasure by associating himself with the organization.

UST at this time, before the actual opening of hostilities, as it were, it will
not be altogether inappropriate to take a momentary retrospect of our
past achievements in the athletic world. Let it be clearly understood,
however, that this mention is made, not out of any spirit of egotism, but merely
to give Hopkins her just dues—as if we were a disinterested party—by a simple
statement of facts that are unfortunately unknown to many of our members.
Principal among these facts, is that all the State Records, with but two exceptions, are held by our men. Every loyal son of Hopkins should feel in this a
personal pride, as well as an individual responsibility, in holding these records.
We cannot afford to rest content with the laurels won in the past, but must strive
to emulate and even to surpass the feats of our predecessors. By relaxing our
efforts, even for a single moment, we may lose a reputation that it has taken
years to acquire. As it is not improbable that some of the present records will
be broken during the coming season, and as other collegeg and clubs are pro
ducing good men who will push ours to the limit, we should all be possessed
with a grim determination to keep these records right "in the family," In
addition to this list of enviable records, our athletic prowess is further shown in
that we have won the Inter Collegiate Championship of Mar)land and the District of Columbia every .year from 1897 to 1901, when the League disbanded,
except in 1899, when we did not compete. Also, in the University of Pennsylvania Relay Races, out of seven annual contests from 1896 to date, we have
won four firsts, two seconds, and one third. The banners on the walls of the
Trophy Room, as well as the cabinet well filled with other trophies, bear witness to our athletic prowess. Each is indicative of a close contest and a hardearned victory. Our past has been an unbroken series of triumphs, may our
future surpass even our former efforts!

VISIT OF MR. JAYS.

HE recent visit of Mr. Tom. Jays to the colleges of Baltimore has been
accompanied with considerable interest to a good many men.
Mr. Jays arrived in town Thursday afternoon, January 8th, and was
put up at the Hopkins Club. That e-ening he met the leaders of the medical
and dental school associations at a supper at the Central Y. M. C. A. Friday
and Saturday were spent visiting these colleges, where he was given the time
of some lecture and spoke to between moo and 1200 men.
On Saturday afternoon, in Levering Hall, he met twenty of the student
volunteers of the city and encouraged and inspired them by his intense earnestness and power.
Following this, at 6.30 twenty.eight men from Hopkins and a few other
colleges sat down to an informal supper in the reading room of Levering Hall.
After the supper Dr. Wilson introduced Mr. Jays, and he gave us a short talk
on the call to Christian men to devote their lives to the christianizing and
civilizing the people of foreign lands. When he sat down the men began to
ask questions. In this way were brought out, in a very informal, pleasant way,
many interesting and instructive points about such work.
Our arrangements for Sunday were interfered with by the very bad weather,
but about forty men gathered in Levering Hall in the afternoon when Mr. Jays
again made a strong appeal and told some interesting experiences. The men
were so extremely interested that the talk seemed too short. As a result of
these two meetings quite a number of Hopkins men arranged for personal inter_
views on Tuesday. In this way the day was well filled until five o'clock, when
he again spoke to about twenty men, presenting the personal Christ to them
very forcibly.
Monday was spent chiefly at the Medical School where he attended some
of the clinics. Mr. Jays says Hopkins is considered in England as a "mecca"
for medical men. In the evening he spoke to an interested group of students
and faculty members in the Association Reading Room at the hospital.
It will be a difficult matter to estimate the results of this visit. It will take
time to tell what they will be. Many men realize more than ever before in their
lives that the whole world is open to them to choose a place to invest their
life, that Jesus Christ has a claim on their lives for best investment, and they
can never again be excused for not thinking about it. It means men interested
in the cause of foreign missions whether they go or stay at home. And by
God's blessing it means some men give their lives very definitely for this form
of service. It is not a far-off question. It is, which of us shall it be?

HE Angry Mob was sitting quietly in the barber shop when the Poet
started the discussion. "I see," he remarked casually, "that the season
of the year is approaching when it behooves the Junior Class to hand in
some sonnets to keep Dr. Greene from reading Anglo-Saxon to them."
"I tried to write a sonnet once," confessed the Fusser, "but there were too
few words to rhyme with love and with sorrow; love, dove, glove, above, borrow, sorrow, tomorrow, that about exhausts the supply."
"Was it an Italian Sonnet ?" queried the Italian, whom the Bugologist
addresses as Mr. Dinklebender.
"It was not, it was better," said the Fusser, "it was a sonnet I originated." At this moment the Cdief Supe broke in.
"Malatesta! Say nothing against the Italian." The Captain of the Supes
squelched the Chief Supe with one lightning glance. The Poet brought them
back to the matter in hand
"I am preparing some sonnets," he ventured timidly, "which might be of
use to the members of the Junior Class—at the usual market rates. There is
nothing hard about a sonnet."
The Fusser sighed, the Bugologist looked incredulous, and Walter absentmindedly lathered the hair of the Chief Supe.
"All that is necessary is to understand the words which you want to use,
and then put them together. I have taken the following rhymes, after the
usual a, b, b, a, manner, and fitted them together in the most approved
poetic fashion: steal, heart, apart, unseal, feel, start, chart, reveal. That shall
be my octave; now for the sestet, learn, past, guide, return, cast, purified.
Good. Now, gentlemen, what shall it be first?"
The Objector, skilled in opposition in the senate, thought to stump the
poet; "Give us," he cried, "something in contemplation's deepest mood."
The poet turned as pale as the Chief Supe's hair. Pulling himself together,
however, he produced the following:

SOLITUDB.

There is a balm in silence which doth steal
With soothing power into the weary heart,
What joy we find it is to dwell apart
In realms of silence where we can unseal
The inmost chambers of the heart, and feel
No searching eye is here to make us start
With dread surprise by gazing on the chart
Of our life's deeds which doth the past reveal.
So in the sacred silence do we learn
To live aright by thinking on the past;
And by the past our future steps to guide.
When once again we to the world return,—
That busy mart, wherein our lives are cast,—
By silence have our hearts been purified.

The college boy or girl is, in the language of genetic psychology, an adolescent. This
stage of the development of the individual is marked off at its beginning by the advent of
puberty and at its close by the full maturity of the reproductive organs. In boys this
covers the time front about the fourteenth to the twenty fifth year, and in girls front about
the thirteenth to the twenty•second year. The college student is, thus, in the latter part
of this stage of development. We shall then have to inquire into the characteristics of the
adolescent in general, and then call especial attention to the manner and extent of the
manifestations of those characteristics in the latter part of this stage of development.
Rousseau defines this period as the time when the child is born again, having at birth
been born cc an individual, and itow into the life of the race. There is much truth in this
statement, even though we may not wish to follow it out to all its logical consequences.

But front the mental standpoint the change is even more marked. And since it is this
alone that concerns us today, we may pass on without further comment upon the physical
development of this period, and the laws of physical hygiene to be observed during its
continuance.
Accompanying these physical changes there is a tremendous increase in the store of
nervous energy, which must have some outlet. He is fully awakened and aroused to
everything in his environment. Everything takes on a new meaning because he penetrates
deeper into the inter relations of things, and for the first time the interpretation of events
and things given by the adult, begins to dawn in its reality. The change in point of view
from that of the girl to that of the adult takes place rapidly, far more so than most of us
think, and in its non.recognition lie many of the errors of parents and teachers to day.
One day he is a boy, the next he is a man, is almost literally true. Certainly the time of
transition is not many months in length. To be sure, the way has been prepared, and the
observer can easily see the bearing of the acts of the pre-adolescent toward this culmination
period, and to the careless observer there seems no distant separation, but I thoroughly
believe that there is a time when the boy or girl conies to a distinct consciousness that now
I am a man or a woman, whereas, before I was a boy or a girl, and that from that time
there is such a new element in his personality, discernable to the keen sympathetic companion, that must be reckoned with in all dealings with him to such an extent as to
require in some respects a radically different attitude toward him.
In this great outpouring of nervous energy into new channels, naturally the emotional
side is most in evidence. The new desires, the new interests which must necessarily result from this great outpouring, cannot help going to great and extreme bounds in their
manifestations. Use is made of the intellectual powers already possessed in the new
fields, but those powers are limited necessarily. Judgment and reason and experience being deficient, what wonder is it that there are such ludicrous hopes, such senseless dreams,
such impossible ambitions as are secretly guiding the acts, and really almost entirely the
being the lives of these young people It is not often that another is allowed, to enter this
holy of holies; but we can easily conjecture what is therein, and so help take care of the
treasure that it may some day yield its full increase in the service of the world. This is
the key which unlocks the gate to the avenue of success for all those who are concerned
with the development of youth into true vigorous adulthood—the protection of this holy of
holies, seeing as far as is possible only those things which count for good remain long
therein.

all the other sides of mental life as well, there is a striking difference in the emotional

Turning next to the intellectual life of the adolescent, we find these new increased and
deeper interests causing more keen perceptions over a wider range of matter. Wider gen eralization, and more definiteness and accuracy in the analysis and synthesis of more
abundant details are possible. That is, his capacity has grown both extensively and in.
. He can embrace a wider range, and at the same time keep in hand a more refined elaboration of the facts already known as wholes. It is the age of the reason preeminently, when each for himself establishes the interrelatedness of things in his own life
and in his environment It differs from the previous age in that in the former he does not
inquire into the interdependences of phenomena in any more than a superficial way. He
takes the explanations offered as sufficient, and is not disposed to go back of them. While
in this latter period this new energy forces him beyond, and he will not be satisfied until
he has exhausted for himself all those resources which he can command or comprehend.
In the execution of his thoughts and desires, the adolescent at this period for the first
time really enters upon the plane of independent action. He feels the power within him
to do as he pleases. The influence of parents is apt to diminish, unless he is approached upon
this new plane; authority as represented in the school declines as well, if not properly
adapted. In any case he obeys the tribunal within his own mind; he has become fully
self-determining. He obeys not from force of compulsion, but of his own inner freedom,
and he wishes to be held responsible for his acts. His acts of will will now be much
longer sustained than formerly; he has greater powers of application with frequent spells
of inaction and activity, occuring less often with advancing age; he is not so easily turned
aside from the accomplishment of his desires. All in all, it is a time of intense, enthusiastic, indedendent activity.
Morally, the adolescent is an uncertain quantity, in some cases almost wholly good, in
others almost wholly bad, usually an admixture of the two, and his life is the struggle for
the mastery by these two forces. Extreme cases of evil in youths, whose acts are usually
strictly moral, are not really so abnormal as most people think. On the opposite extreme
We meet self infliction of penance in an undue degree for little or imaginary wrongs. It
is the time when vows and pledges are made, and when the religious life is intelligently
entered upon. There is in all this a patient persistent seeking for the foundation and true
interpretation of things in the moral life, as well as in the strictly intellectual.
He becomes more active in his social relations than ever before. The realization that
he is but a unit in a great social whole, upon which he is dependent, and from which he
gains most that he has, and to which he must in turn contribute his share begins to make
itself felt gradually. The institutions of society take on a new meaning, and he re-adapts
himself to them in a new way. He plans as to what place he shall take in the social group,
inquires into its constitution more closely, find weaknesses or needs and plans reforms.
Methods whereby his fellows may be united for the accomplishment of some end which
he has in view, with himself at the head, are studied and put into practice. The closest
friendships of life, and which often last through its course, are at this time formed, as well
as those loves which later develop into the relations of the marital life.

VISIT OF MR. JAYS.

HE recent visit of Mr. Tom. Jays to the colleges of Baltimore has been
accompanied with considerable interest to a good many men.
Mr. Jays arrived in town Thursday afternoon, January 8th, and was
put up at the Hopkins Club. That e-ening he met the leaders of the medical
and dental school associations at a supper at the Central Y. M. C. A. Friday
and Saturday were spent visiting these colleges, where he was given the time
of some lecture and spoke to between moo and 1200 men.
On Saturday afternoon, in Levering Hall, he met twenty of the student
volunteers of the city and encouraged and inspired them by his intense earnestness and power.
Following this, at 6.30 twenty.eight men from Hopkins and a few other
colleges sat down to an informal supper in the reading room of Levering Hall.
After the supper Dr. Wilson introduced Mr. Jays, and he gave us a short talk
on the call to Christian men to devote their lives to the christianizing and
civilizing the people of foreign lands. When he sat down the men began to
ask questions. In this way were brought out, in a very informal, pleasant way,
many interesting and instructive points about such work.
Our arrangements for Sunday were interfered with by the very bad weather,
but about forty men gathered in Levering Hall in the afternoon when Mr. Jays
again made a strong appeal and told some interesting experiences. The men
were so extremely interested that the talk seemed too short. As a result of
these two meetings quite a number of Hopkins men arranged for personal inter_
views on Tuesday. In this way the day was well filled until five o'clock, when
he again spoke to about twenty men, presenting the personal Christ to them
very forcibly.
Monday was spent chiefly at the Medical School where he attended some
of the clinics. Mr. Jays says Hopkins is considered in England as a "mecca"
for medical men. In the evening he spoke to an interested group of students
and faculty members in the Association Reading Room at the hospital.
It will be a difficult matter to estimate the results of this visit. It will take
time to tell what they will be. Many men realize more than ever before in their
lives that the whole world is open to them to choose a place to invest their
life, that Jesus Christ has a claim on their lives for best investment, and they
can never again be excused for not thinking about it. It means men interested
in the cause of foreign missions whether they go or stay at home. And by
God's blessing it means some men give their lives very definitely for this form
of service. It is not a far-off question. It is, which of us shall it be?

HE Angry Mob was sitting quietly in the barber shop when the Poet
started the discussion. "I see," he remarked casually, "that the season

some sonnets to keep Dr. Greene from reading Anglo-Saxon to them."

addresses as Mr. Dinklebender.
"It was not, it was better," said the Fusser, "it was a sonnet I originated." At this moment the Cdief Supe broke in.

squelched the Chief Supe with one lightning glance. The Poet brought them

"I am preparing some sonnets," he ventured timidly, "which might be of
use to the members of the Junior Class—at the usual market rates. There is

"All that is necessary is to understand the words which you want to use,

poetic fashion: steal, heart, apart, unseal, feel, start, chart, reveal. That shall

There is a balm in silence which doth steal
With soothing power into the weary heart,

The inmost chambers of the heart, and feel
No searching eye is here to make us start
With dread surprise by gazing on the chart
Of our life's deeds which doth the past reveal.
So in the sacred silence do we learn
To live aright by thinking on the past;
And by the past our future steps to guide.
When once again we to the world return,—
